resources.string: RDYMSG commands, or ready message commands, are used to change a printer\'s \'ready\' message. \n\nThis has many entertaining possibilities - I recommend trying things like \'insert coin\' or \'out of cheese\'.

OPMSG commands, or operator message commands, are intended to display a message on the printer which can be canceled by pressing the printer\'s \'ok\' button. \nThese commands will behave differently on different models - possible behaviors include beeping, pausing printing, or flashing a light when an OPMSG is received.

Overview: 
This application is designed to be able to use a standard called PJL, or Printer Job Language, to change the ready message on certain types of printers. It is also capable of sending commands which will cause printers to display an 'operator message' to the user. 
The primary use for this program is probably pranking, but it certaintly has the potential for other, more legitimate uses as well. 
 
How to use: 
To use this program, you need to do two things: 
- Figure out the IP of the network printer you wish to hack 
- Connect to a wifi network where the printer is accessible 
Once you've got that taken care of, simply open the program, input your message, and click one of the two commands below the message box. 
 
How to find your printer's IP: 
There are two ways to find the IP of your network printer. The first is to print a network report using the printer's menu. Most printers which support PJL will have this option under 'reports' or 'status'. The second way is to find the IP by looking up the printer on a computer which is already connected to the printer. You can find instructions for how to do this at http://www.findmyip.org/find-network-printer-ip.php

About Printerhack: 
Printerhack is written by Quinn Rohlf and the core printer code is licensed under the Apache 2.0 open source license. You can view the source at http://qrohlf.com. The program was originally developed just for my own amusement, and after a friend found it and played around with it at school, I realized that there was probably a market for this sort of thing. The version you're using is a much more polished version than the original, and was written with the intent of making a little bit of money for college. 
 
Actually, money for college is one of the main goals I have with Android development, so it would be really cool of you to donate via my website!

Hi, I'm an 18 year old student who does Android development in his spare time. If you found this app helpful or useful, it would be really rad if you would donate to me, either by buying the donate version of this app in the Market, or by donating via the paypal button on my website. If you do, I'll probably send you a postcard or a beta version of one of my apps. 
 
Cheers, 
-QRohlf
